response_metadata.response_text:
{
  "overview": "The purpose and intent of this measure is to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent and to establish a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit. This measure is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs. The Judiciary is also required to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit.",
  "appropriations": "The measure inserts an appropriation amount of $514,900 (HB727) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) for fiscal year 2026-2027. These funds are designated for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. The measure also deletes language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health for an unspecified number of temporary positions.",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The appropriations are based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure, which identified the need to close the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area. The decision to expand the program is informed by the success of the First Circuit's Mohala Wahine pilot program, which has been operational since January 2023. The cost estimations cover services and staffing for the new three-year pilot program.",
  "agency_impact": "This measure will have a direct impact on the Judiciary by making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent and establishing a new three-year pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. The new program will be under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court and will require two temporary positions. The Judiciary is also tasked with submitting a report to the Legislature no later than forty days prior to the Regular Session of 2026.",
  "economic_impact": "This measure aims to enhance community safety by reducing recidivism through evidence-based, trauma-informed care. The existing Women's Court Pilot Program has been successful, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. The program will support women dealing with trauma, abuse, and unhealthy relationships by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems.",
  "policy_impact": "This measure amends state law by making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit, established by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, permanent. It establishes a new three-year pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the originally proposed Second and Fifth Circuits. The measure also deletes the requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study, instead moving directly to establish and fund the pilot program.",
  "revenue_sources": "The document does not specify the revenue source for the appropriations. The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the new pilot program in the Third Circuit. These funds are appropriated for services and two temporary positions.",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The fiscal implications for the next six years include an appropriation of $514,900 (HB727) in fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) in fiscal year 2026-2027 for the three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit. These funds are for services and two temporary positions. Funding for the third year of the pilot program in fiscal year 2027-2028 is not specified but would be necessary for the program's completion. The measure also makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, implying ongoing operating costs, though no specific appropriation for this is included. The Judiciary is also required to submit a report to the Legislature prior to the Regular Session of 2026, which may lead to future fiscal implications if it recommends program expansion to the Second and Fifth Circuits.",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided document does not indicate any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from this measure. The program is funded through legislative appropriations. There is no mention of fees for services or other revenue streams.",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided document does not outline any expected capital expenditures related to this measure. The appropriations are specified for \"services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit\" (HB727). No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure are mentioned.",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit is established as a three-year pilot, meaning its continuation beyond fiscal year 2028 would require further legislative action and appropriation. The measure makes the First Circuit's Mohala Wahine Pilot Program permanent, indicating an ongoing fiscal obligation to sustain its annual operating costs indefinitely. The long-term fiscal impact will depend on the success of the pilot program and future decisions to expand the model to other circuits.",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison. This fiscal note is based solely on the analysis of H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, S.D. 1."
}

sentence_attributions.sentence:
{
  "overview": "The purpose and intent of this measure is to make the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent and to establish a three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit
This measure is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs

The Judiciary is also required to submit a report to the Legislature regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Fifth Circuits and the Hilo division of the Third Circuit

",
  "appropriations": "The measure inserts an appropriation amount of $514,900 (HB727) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) for fiscal year 2026-2027
These funds are designated for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit
The measure also deletes language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health for an unspecified number of temporary positions

",
  "assumptions_and_methodology": "The appropriations are based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure, which identified the need to close the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area
The decision to expand the program is informed by the success of the First Circuit's Mohala Wahine pilot program, which has been operational since January 2023
The cost estimations cover services and staffing for the new three-year pilot program

",
  "agency_impact": "This measure will have a direct impact on the Judiciary by making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent and establishing a new three-year pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit
The new program will be under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court and will require two temporary positions
The Judiciary is also tasked with submitting a report to the Legislature no later than forty days prior to the Regular Session of 2026

",
  "economic_impact": "This measure aims to enhance community safety by reducing recidivism through evidence-based, trauma-informed care
The existing Women's Court Pilot Program has been successful, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment

The program will support women dealing with trauma, abuse, and unhealthy relationships by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems

",
  "policy_impact": "This measure amends state law by making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit, established by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, permanent
It establishes a new three-year pilot program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the originally proposed Second and Fifth Circuits
The measure also deletes the requirement for the Third Circuit to conduct an interim study, instead moving directly to establish and fund the pilot program

",
  "revenue_sources": "The document does not specify the revenue source for the appropriations
The measure appropriates $514,900 (HB727) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) for fiscal year 2026-2027 for the new pilot program in the Third Circuit
These funds are appropriated for services and two temporary positions

",
  "six_year_fiscal_implications": "The fiscal implications for the next six years include an appropriation of $514,900 (HB727) in fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727) in fiscal year 2026-2027 for the three-year Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit
These funds are for services and two temporary positions
Funding for the third year of the pilot program in fiscal year 2027-2028 is not specified but would be necessary for the program's completion
The measure also makes the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent, implying ongoing operating costs, though no specific appropriation for this is included

The Judiciary is also required to submit a report to the Legislature prior to the Regular Session of 2026, which may lead to future fiscal implications if it recommends program expansion to the Second and Fifth Circuits

",
  "operating_revenue_impact": "The provided document does not indicate any anticipated impacts on operating revenues resulting from this measure
The program is funded through legislative appropriations
There is no mention of fees for services or other revenue streams

",
  "capital_expenditure_impact": "The provided document does not outline any expected capital expenditures related to this measure
The appropriations are specified for \"services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit\" (HB727)
No investments in facilities, equipment, or technology infrastructure are mentioned

",
  "fiscal_implications_after_6_years": "The Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit is established as a three-year pilot, meaning its continuation beyond fiscal year 2028 would require further legislative action and appropriation
The measure makes the First Circuit's Mohala Wahine Pilot Program permanent, indicating an ongoing fiscal obligation to sustain its annual operating costs indefinitely
The long-term fiscal impact will depend on the success of the pilot program and future decisions to expand the model to other circuits

",
  "updates_from_previous_fiscal_note": "No previous fiscal note was provided for comparison
This fiscal note is based solely on the analysis of H

chunk_details.chunk_text: SSCR1240 STAND. COM. REP. NO. 1240 Honolulu, Hawaii RE: H.B. No. 727 H.D. 1 S.D. 1 Honorable Ronald D. Kouchi President of the Senate Thirty-Third State Legislature Regular Session of 2025 State of Hawaii Sir: Your Committee on Judiciary, to which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A

which was referred H.B. No. 727, H.D. 1, entitled: "A BILL FOR AN ACT RELATING TO THE WOMEN'S COURT," begs leave to report as follows: The purpose and intent of this measure is to: (1) Establish a three—year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and

Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Second and Fifth Circuits, which is intended to acknowledge the distinct pathways that lead women into the criminal justice system and address their individualized needs; and (2) Require the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an

the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit. Your Committee received testimony in support of this measure from the Judiciary, Department of Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental

Health, Office of the Public Defender, State Council on Mental Health, Department of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Maui, Office of the Prosecuting Attorney of the County of Hawai ʻ i, County of Hawai ʻ i Committee on the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii

the Status of Women, Hawaii Substance Abuse Coalition, West Hawaii Bar Association, Community Alliance on Prisons, and nine individuals. Your Committee finds that Mohala Wahine, or the State's Women's Court three-year pilot program, was established in the First Circuit by Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been

Act 243, Session Laws of Hawaii 2022, and has been operational since January 2023. The mission of Mohala Wahine is to assist and guide participants in meeting their legal and statutory responsibilities and to facilitate change in the participants' well-being by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the

by providing gender-responsive services that uphold the mission of the State's Judiciary and the Adult Client Services Branch. Additionally, Mohala Wahine aims to enhance community safety by reducing recidivism through evidence-based, trauma-informed care, and cultural practices. Your Committee further finds that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been

that thus far, the Women's Court Pilot Program has been successful, with eleven participants in phase one of treatment and twelve participants in phase two of treatment. Given the success of the First District's Mohala Wahine, your Committee believes that the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee

the Mohala Wahine Pilot Program should become permanent. Your Committee additionally finds that the Third Circuit, specifically the Kona area, is at a disadvantage to address crime motivators such as substance abuse, mental health, and homelessness, given its limited community resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities,

resources and funding, geographic restrictions, limitations of court supervision authorities, overcrowded correctional facilities, understaffed law enforcement, and shortage of direct service providers. Additionally, Hawaii County has the highest poverty rate in the State, high rates of domestic violence, and limited opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who

opportunities for employment, all of which disproportionately impact women, who are more likely to be victims of violence and more likely to have dependent children in their care. Your Committee believes that, based on data and information provided by the Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure,

Judiciary in testimony at the public hearing on this measure, closing the service gap for the most at-risk women in the Kona area of the Third District is imperative. This measure will support women in the State dealing with trauma, abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment,

abuse, unhealthy relationships, and more by providing substance abuse treatment, mental health support, and assistance with navigating the criminal and social services systems. Accordingly, your Committee has amended this measure by: (1) Inserting language making the Women's Court Pilot Program in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establishing a three—year Women's

in the First Circuit permanent; (2) Establishing a three—year Women's Court Pilot Program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the Third Circuit, rather than the Second and Fifth Circuits; (3) Specifying that the Women's Court Pilot Program is under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court;

is under the supervision of the Big Island Drug Court; (4) Inserting an appropriation amount of $514,900 for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 for fiscal year 2026-2027 for services and two temporary positions for the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (5) Deleting language

the Kona division of the Third Circuit; (5) Deleting language that would have appropriated an unspecified amount of funds to the Department of Health for an unspecified number of temporary positions; (6) Deleting language that would have required the Third Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to

Circuit of the Judiciary and Big Island Drug Court to conduct an interim study to establish a blueprint for a Women's Court Pilot Program in the Third Circuit; (7) Requiring the Judiciary to submit a report to the Legislature no later than forty days prior to the Regular Session of

later than forty days prior to the Regular Session of 2026 regarding the need for and the associated costs of a pilot program for Women's Court in the Second and Firth Circuits and Hilo division of the Third Circuit; (8) Amending section 1 to reflect its amended purpose; (9) Inserting
Amending section 1 to reflect its amended purpose; (9) Inserting an effective date of April 23, 2057, to encourage further disc
